entry.title: Handwritten Digits Recognition
entry.content:
Abstract Statistical methods are widely used in image recognition or classification nowadays and can produce pretty satisfying results. MNIST database is a large public database of handwritten digits that is commonly used for training and testing recognizers or classifiers based on various statistical models. In this paper, several models- including discriminant analysis, k-nearest neighbor, kernel SVM, random forests, and neural networks- are described theoretically and then applied to this database. PCA helps to reduce data dimension in some cases. Testing error rates of all models are compared.
Keywords: Statistical Learning, MNIST, Dimension Reduction, PCA, Discriminant Analysis, K-nearest Neighbor, Kernel SVM, Random Forests, Neural Network, Deep Learning, Testing Error Rate.

Introduction

    MNIST is a handwritten digits image data set created by Yann LeCun. Each image is 282828 pixels in height and 282828 pixels in width i.e. 784784784 pixels in total, so is represented as a vector in 784−D784-D784−D space. The training dataset includes 600006000060000 images, while the testing dataset 100001000010000 images.

    Our goal is to train different classifiers with training dataset and then use trained classifiers to recognize handwritten digits from testing dataset as accurately as possible.

     From the MNIST dataset, we can obtain large data matrix. The first column is the label of each image. The input pixels in the rest columns are greyscale value, with a value of 0.00.00.0 representing white, a value of 1.01.01.0 representing black, and values in [0.0,1.0][0.0,1.0][0.0,1.0] representing gradually darkening shades of grey. To locate a specific pixel on the image, suppose that we have decomposed xxx as x=i∗28+jx = i * 28 + jx=i∗28+j, where iii and jjj are integers between 000 and 272727, inclusive. Then pixel xxx is located on row iii and column jjj of a 28×2828\times2828×28 matrix, (indexing by zero). Images can be restored as the following figure (1) shows.

Figure 1: Restored digit images
    In the field of image recognition and classification, statistical methods are widely used. Since the MNIST dataset is so large that some methods run very slow, we first introduce PCA, a common dimension reduction technique. Result show that the first $55 - 60$ principal components can explain over $85\%$ of total variance, so in some cases, we use those components instead of original data.     We then try different models and analyze the MNIST dataset from various perspectives. We apply k-nearest neighbor, SVM, random forests and neural network, roughly in the order of complexity. Given the sufficient training data and proper parameters, we all get pretty satisfying recognizers which perform well on testing data and the error rates can be controlled at a very low level. We give a curve of error rates in the last section.##PCA and Dimension Reduction    Principal component analysis(PCA) is an nonparametric method, which converts a set of observations of correlated variables into a set of values of linearly uncorrelated variables, i.e. principal components.     For a random vector $\mathbf{x}\in \mathbb{R}^p$ with covariance structure $cov(\mathbf{x}) = \sigma$, then the principal components of population are $\alpha_i\mathbf{x}, i = 1,2,\cdots,p$.     For data sample, suppose the data matrix $\mathbf{X}_{n\times p} = (X_1,\cdots, X_p)$, where $n$ is the number of observations. Assume $rank(\mathbf{X}) = p < n$, and $\mathbf{X}$ has been centralized i.e. $\mathbf{1}^TX_i = 0, i = 1,2,\cdots,p$. Then $\text{cov}(\mathbf{X}) = \frac{1}{n-1}\mathbf{X}^T\mathbf{X}$.     Suppose $\mathbf{X}$ has singular value decomposition: $\mathbf{X} = \mathbf{UDV}^T$, then $\mathbf{X}^T\mathbf{X} = \mathbf{VD}^2\mathbf{V}^T$, which means the diagonal elements of $\mathbf{D}$ are eigenvalues of $\mathbf{X}^T\mathbf{X}$ and the columns of $\mathbf{V}$ are corresponding eigenvectors. $\mathbf{XV}$ denotes the PC score.     For the training data $\mathbf{X}^{train}$ from MNIST, $n = 60000, p = 784$, the variances of the first $60$ components and cumulative variance proportion are shown below in figure (2) and (3).     We find that the first $60$ components explain over $85\%$ of total variance. Denote $\mathbf{T}$ as the first $60$ columns of $\mathbf{V}$, it is acceptable to use $\mathbf{X}^{train}\mathbf{T}, \mathbf{X}^{test}\mathbf{T}$ instead of original data. By applying PCA, we reduce the dimension MNIST data, which helps to speed up some algorithms. Next we visualize the results of PCA.
Figure 2: Variance of ﬁrst $60$ PCs
Figure 3: Cumulative variance proportion of PCs
    Figure (4) shows the "eigenfaces" from the first $18$ PC loadings. Then we reconstruct the images based on the first $60$ PCs.
Figure 4: First $18$ eigenfaces
    Figure (5) shows comparison between raw images and reconstructed ones. It proves again that using the first $60$ PCS is an acceptable choice.
Figure 5: Comparison: raw VS reconstructed
Figure 1: Restored digit images
## Discriminant AnalysisConsider modelling $P(Y = k|X = x), k = 1,2,\cdots,10$, discriminant analysis model the distribution of the predictors $X$ given $Y$ and then estimate $P(Y = k|X = x)$ by Bayesian theorem i.e.$$ \begin{aligned} P(Y=k|X=x) = \frac{\pi_kP(X=x|Y=k)}{\sum_{l=1}^K\pi_lP(X=x|Y=l)} := \frac{\pi_kf_k(x)}{\sum_{l=1}^K\pi_lf_l(x)},\qquad(1) \end{aligned}$$where $\pi_k$ denotes the prior probability of the $k$th class.

Linear Discriminant Analysis

LDA recognizer assumes that the observation from the kkkth digit are drawn from Gaussian distribution N(μk,Σ)N(\mu_k, \Sigma)N(μk​,Σ), where Σ\SigmaΣ is common among all digits. Then

fk(x)=Cexp⁡[−12(x−μk)TΣ−1(x−μk)],(2) f_k(x) = C\exp\left[-\frac{1}{2}(x-\mu_k)^T\Sigma^{-1}(x-\mu_k)\right],\qquad (2)fk​(x)=Cexp[−21​(x−μk​)TΣ−1(x−μk​)],(2)

where CCC is a constant. Plugging equation (2) into (1) reveals that LDA assigns X=xX = xX=x to the class where

δk(x)=xTΣ−1μk−12μkTΣ−1μk+log⁡πk \delta_k(x) = x^T\Sigma^{-1}\mu_k - \frac{1}{2}\mu_k^T\Sigma^{-1}\mu_k + \log\pi_kδk​(x)=xTΣ−1μk​−21​μkT​Σ−1μk​+logπk​

is largest.
Several pixels of original MNIST dataset are constant which LDA cannot handle, so we use the first 606060 principal components instead and do related analysis. LDA generates a rough linear classifier, whose error rate on testing data is 12.38%12.38\%12.38%. This means that our assumption that all digits share the same covariance structure is not very reasonable. So we turn to QDA.

Quadratic Discriminant Analysis

QDA assumes the kkkth class has own covariance matrix Σk\Sigma_kΣk​. Under this assumption, QDA recognizer assigns an observation X=xX = xX=x to the class where

δk(x)=−12xTΣk−1x+xTΣk−1μk−12μkTΣk−1μk−12log⁡det⁡Σk+log⁡πk \delta_k(x) = -\frac{1}{2}x^T\Sigma_k^{-1}x + x^T\Sigma_k^{-1}\mu_k - \frac{1}{2}\mu_k^T\Sigma_k^{-1}\mu_k - \frac{1}{2}\log\det{\Sigma_k} + \log\pi_kδk​(x)=−21​xTΣk−1​x+xTΣk−1​μk​−21​μkT​Σk−1​μk​−21​logdetΣk​+logπk​

is largest.
    Again for the same reason, we use the first 606060 PCs instead. This time the error rate decreases to 3.88%3.88\%3.88%, which improves a lot compared to LDA. This result shows the covariance structure is indeed different among digits, which we guess is probably due to different structures of digits. We are not very satisfied with the performance of discriminant analysis, so we consider a nonparametric model-- k-nearest neighbor.

K-nearest Neighbor

Given x0x_0x0​ to be recognized, KNN recognizer picks KKK points in the training data that are closest to x0x_0x0​, denoted as N0N_0N0​. Then it estimates

P(Y=k∣X=x0)=1K∑i∈N0I(yi=k). P(Y = k|X= x_0) = \frac{1}{K}\sum_{i\in N_0}I_{(y_i = k)}.P(Y=k∣X=x0​)=K1​i∈N0​∑​I(yi​=k)​.

Finally, it classifies x0x_0x0​ to the class with the largest probability. KNN is quite intuitive but lacks in efficiency and the choice of KKK is tricky.
    We apply KNN to original data and PCs respectively and set K=5K = 5K=5. The error rate is 3.12%3.12\%3.12% for the former and 2.47%2.47\%2.47% for the latter. PCs may filter uncorrelated pixels that even worsen the performance of KNN. Next we will try some more complex models in statistical learning.

Kernel Support Vector Machine

For a two-class recognition problem with non-linear class boundaries, kernel SVM enlarges the feature space to accommodate the boundaries, by using various kernels including polynomial kernel K(xi,xj)=(1+⟨xi,xj⟩)dK(x_i,x_j) = (1+\langle x_i,x_j\rangle)^dK(xi​,xj​)=(1+⟨xi​,xj​⟩)d, Gaussian kernel K(xi,xj)=exp⁡(−γ∥xi−xj∥2)K(x_i,x_j) = \exp(-\gamma\|x_i-x_j\|^2)K(xi​,xj​)=exp(−γ∥xi​−xj​∥2), etc. First project the data into a high-dimensional space

xi:→ϕ(xi,⋅), x_i :\rightarrow\phi(x_i,\cdot),xi​:→ϕ(xi​,⋅),

Then define the inner product K(xi,xj)K(x_i,x_j)K(xi​,xj​), where K(⋅,⋅)K(\cdot,\cdot)K(⋅,⋅) is a non-linear kernel function. The recognizer f(x)f(x)f(x) has the form

f(x)=β0+∑i∈SαiyiK(x,xi).(3) f(x) = \beta_0 + \sum_{i\in S}\alpha_iy_iK(x,x_i).\qquad (3)f(x)=β0​+i∈S∑​αi​yi​K(x,xi​).(3)

    The coefficients in equation (3) can be obtained by solving a constrained optimization problem, where the dual function is given by

Ld=∑iαi−12∑i∑jαiαjyiyjK(xi,xj).L_d = \sum_i\alpha_i - \frac{1}{2}\sum_i\sum_j\alpha_i\alpha_jy_iy_jK(x_i,x_j).Ld​=i∑​αi​−21​i∑​j∑​αi​αj​yi​yj​K(xi​,xj​).

    If the recognition problem extends to KKK-class case, there are two popular ways: one-versus-one and one-versus-all. The former one trains K(K−1)2\frac{K(K-1)}{2}2K(K−1)​ SVMs, each of which recognizes a pair of classes. The latter one trains (K−1)(K-1)(K−1) SVMs, each of which recognizes one class from all other classes.
    We try three kinds of SVM and their performances vary a bit, as listed below.

  • SVM: Gaussian kernel, 2.68%2.68\%2.68%, trained with original data;
  • SVM: Gaussian kernel, 2.58%2.58\%2.58%, trained with the first 606060 PCs;
  • SVM: 333-order Polynomial kernel, 2.01%2.01\%2.01%, trained with the first 606060 PCs.

    It seems the last one outperforms the other two and again using PCs is a better choice. Limited by time and space, we don’t tune the order of polynomials or the kind of kernel functions, but these are worth trying.

Random Forests

Random forests build a large collection of de-correlated trees and then average them. The implementation is described as follows.

  • For l=1,2,⋯ ,Ll = 1,2,\cdots,Ll=1,2,⋯,L
    • Draw a bootstrap sample;
      • Grow a tree TlT_lTl​ to the sample:
        • Select mmm variables, m≤pm \leq pm≤p;
        • Pick the best split point and split the node into two;
  • Ensemble trees {Tl}\{T_l\}{Tl​};
  • The classification result Crf(x)=arg⁡max⁡#{k:Cl(x)=k}C_{rf}(x) = \arg\max \#\{k: C_l(x) = k\}Crf​(x)=argmax#{k:Cl​(x)=k}.

    Random forests often perform very well in image recognition. But when we set L=25L = 25L=25, the error rate reaches 3.83%3.83\%3.83%, which is an ordinary result. The reason may be the number of trees needs to be larger, but larger number means more cost of time and RAM, so we has to make the trade-off.

Neural Network

First we review some important definitions in neural network theory. A neuron is a real-value function defined on Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd given by

g(x)=σ(aTx+b), g(x) = \sigma(a^Tx + b),g(x)=σ(aTx+b),

where σ(⋅)\sigma(\cdot)σ(⋅) is also called an activation function. A hidden layer contains kkk neurons and corresponds to a non-linear transformation:

f(x)=∑i=1kciσ(aiTx+bi)+c0. f(x) = \sum_{i=1}^kc_i\sigma(a_i^Tx + b_i) + c_0.f(x)=i=1∑k​ci​σ(aiT​x+bi​)+c0​.

    Traditional neural networks are trained by back propagation method, which is actually an iterative method. This will lead to poor efficiency and overfitting problem. Nowadays deep learning methods try to train layer-wise.

Fully Connected Neural Network

In this case, we try a four-layer neural network:

  • Input layer: neurons encoding the values of input pixels;
  • First hidden layer: 128128128 neurons, activation function is f(x)=max⁡(x,0)f(x) = \max(x,0)f(x)=max(x,0);
  • Second hidden layer: 646464 neurons, activation function is f(x)=max⁡(x,0)f(x) = \max(x,0)f(x)=max(x,0);
  • Output layer: 101010 neurons corresponding to 101010 digits, and softmax is used to get a probabilistic prediction.

    We call R package “mxnet” to train our network and get a error rate of 2.05%2.05\%2.05%. Also we try to replace original data with PCs and the error rate increases slightly to 2.40%2.40\%2.40%.

Convolutional Neural Network

Convolutional neural network has three key points-- local receptive fields, shared weights and pooling. The idea is that a small kernel window is moved over neurons from a prior layer. Every neuron is given by

σ(b+local receptive field⊗w), \sigma(b + \text{local receptive field}\otimes w),σ(b+local receptive field⊗w),

where ⊗\otimes⊗ means convolution. Each pair of b,wb, wb,w correspond to a feature map and there can be several different maps on a single layer. Note that weights are shared so the number of parameters is much smaller than fully connected network. Then based on these maps, pooling layers are built, often by max pooling.
    In this case, the structure of CNN is summarized below.

  • First convolution: 5×55\times 55×5 kernel, 202020 filters, activation function is tanh⁡\tanhtanh, max pooling with 2×22\times 22×2 kernel;
  • Second convolution: 5×55\times 55×5 kernel, 505050 filters, activation function is tanh⁡\tanhtanh, max pooling with 2×22\times 22×2 kernel;
  • First full connection: 500500500 neurons, activation function is tanh⁡\tanhtanh;
  • Second full connection: 101010 neurons;
  • Output: sofmax is used to get a probabilistic prediction.

     Note that we need to reshape our original data first. And CNN finally reaches an error rate of 1.00%1.00\%1.00%, which is very impressive.

Summary

Figure (6) summarizes the performances of all recognizers. In fact, every result is pretty satisfying except LDA. Thanks to the large amount of training data, every recognizer is trained sufficiently. But some recognizers which are expected to produce surprising results, such as random forests, performs not that well. We think the reason is that some parameters are chosen empirically thus not very proper, weakening the overall performance. There are many tricky parameters that are listed in table (1). So how to choose “right” parameters is another topic to be studied in the future.
